author: Alex Apple
title: Murder suspect's ex faces charges in armed standoff
text:
BARRE, Vt. - It took several hours for the Washington County Sheriff's Department to bring the suspect, Henry Premont to his arraignment because he was in the state's custody due to mental health concerns.
Henry Premont, the man who was involved in an hour armed standoff with police Wednesday was screaming for his ex-girlfriend at the scene. That ex-girlfriend is a name very familiar to Vermonters.
Police say when Premont walked out of Rickie's Shell Station in Barre Town Wednesday he seemingly wanted police to shoot him.
"Premont specifically asked the troopers to blast him," said Washington County State's Attorney Scott Williams.
Premont surrendered after a one hour standoff and a day later was arraigned on two misdemeanor charges: disorderly conduct and reckless endangerment.
Williams says police started searching for Premont Wednesday after a concerned relative said he threatened Armageddon if confronted by police.
Court papers show he demanded to speak with his ex-girlfriend and alleged murderer Jody Herring who police say shot a Department for Children and Families social worker last week.
"Mr. Premont walked out of the store with two beer cans in his hand. Dropped one of the beer cans and pulled a pistol from his holster on his right hip," said Williams.
After his court appearance Thursday, Washington County Sheriffs transported Premont back to a mental health facility.
Meanwhile Williams left hoping the string of violence in central Vermont is over.
"I'm cautiously optimistic that this is the last dramatic hiccup of this tragedy," said Williams.
Assistant Attorney General John Treadwell says the investigation into the depths of Jody Herring's three family members is ongoing but no final word on when charges will come.
